Deutsche Bank CEO Christian Sewing is not putting any gloss on what has been a tough week, writing to staff with a call for faith and commitment while the bank works through a series of challenges.

“Let’s be straightforward: the newsflow is not good,” he wrote in a message to staff on Friday, hours after the bank was downgraded by Standard & Poor’s and a day after it emerged that its US unit had been added to a problem-bank watchlist for US regulators.

Nevertheless we still think this is important based on the following rationale.

From the S&P statement this morning we make the following observations;

· The outlook is ‘stable’ rather than ‘negative’, which means that we are unlikely to have another downgrade in the near future. That said, S&P also comment that they would very likely revise down the Stand Alone Credit Profile (SACP) of the group if they ‘see setbacks in the delivery of the updated strategy or signs that 2019 financial objectives could materially slip, leading to a stalling of improving profitability.’

alewis2005 @FATDAZ twitch is weirdly huge
11:29 am
BE11:30am

S&P say that their central scenario assumes that ‘cost cutting measures will be tailored and targeted enough to preserve the bank’s capital markets franchise, in particular in Europe, and avoid substantial revenue loss.’ Over the coming 18 months they say that they will look for ‘evidence that the bank retains the solid support of its clients, and that ‘the bank’s ability to preserve its global capital markets franchise, ..., underpins our stable outlook.’

· Within the strategy plan management is expecting stable market share in FIC and Equities sales & trading, and in Origination & Advisory, 2019 versus 2017. In Q1 2018 there are already signs of market share slippage (which management acknowledged on the Q118 results conference call), and the group is reducing leverage and headcount more aggressively than peers. As such we think these assumptions are a stretch, and we factor in further market share loss in our estimates. We think as a result, that over time we could see the group’s results deviating from the S&P’s central scenario, and so there is a material risk of a further downgrade in the future.

· If the group’s Stand Alone Credit Profile is downgraded to BBB-, the senior unsecured rating would likely be lowered to BB+, i.e. below investment grade. At this point the group would see additional pressure as a counterparty, and this negates the argument for why today’s Issuer Credit Rating downgrade may not be so important.

Note S&P say that on the flip side ‘an upgrade is unlikely in the coming 18 months because we expect the financial benefits of strategic execution in 2018 to become more evident only in 2019 and to represent progress in the ongoing journey rather than its conclusion.’ At that point it would only be the issuer credit rating that would likely be revised.

Since taking over coverage of DBK in June 2017 we were holding on to the belief that the situation could not get worse. We have been proven wrong. The latest update that DBK’s US subsidiaries have been categorized as in a troubled condition, has raised new concerns in spite of some clarification provided by DBK that deficiencies identified by regulators appear to mainly concern processes. However, in our view the risk might be that regulators do not give DBK the time to restructure the business and improve returns with the uncertainty around this potentially negatively impacting operating performance.

BE11:33am

Given the low return, valuing DBK is very subjective. DBK’s cost structure, capital allocation to lower return CIB and little room in its capital ratio prevent an accelerated change in the business and ROTE. The share price can go lower – it went to 0.26x latest TBV in September 2016. In a 2020E sum of the parts valuation, CIB comes out at 0.3x BV. It is currently in the share price at 0.11x BV. Valuing CIB at zero despite EUR36bn of allocated equity implies a valuation at EUR7ps. Potential upside could come from a separation of low return assets. Becoming a European IB could create value but this depends on the marks taken on the legacy assets which usually come before any rerating takes place.

Ultimately, weakening capital adequacy would heighten concerns of DBK as a viable counterparty and could potentially cause a bank run in a worst-case scenario. We point out that DBK’s CET1 leverage ratio was 3.10% in early 2017 just before it raised €8bn in equity, increasing the ratio to 3.47%. Since then, the ratio has fallen due to a combination
of statutory losses and regulatory hits to capital. Going forward, DBK needs to ensure that it
can generate profit and reduce leverage exposure to improve the CET1 leverage ratio, while
aggressively cutting personnel and incurring further regulatory hits to capital. This is a very
fine balancing act, in our view, given that the cost/income ratio (reported) was as high as
93% in 1Q18, and since then the European capital markets environment has become tougher with the re-emergence of political concerns in Italy and Spain.

BE11:36am

There is still material downside to our TP of €8, which is derived from our SoP FV methodology. Our base case is that DBK suffers from severe attrition in revenues and profits across the group as it seeks to cut at least 7,000 employees (from c.97.5k as of end-2017). Our SoP FV methodology includes a capital deficit of €4.7bn, which is the amount we think the bank requires in order to reach an adequate CET1 leverage ratio of 3.75% (consistent with Swiss peers). We forecast an ROTNAV (adjusted) of only 1.0% for FY18 and 3.0% for FY19, which means the stock is expensive despite a relatively low 2019e P/TNAV of 0.40x. There is material downside risk to our TP if evidence emerges that DBK is suffering from deposit outflows.

The CMA enquiry into funeral homes and crematoria adds another layer of uncertainty given that the company is part-way through trials on pricing in funeral homes. The CMA states that it is to look at the clarity of pricing and how it has changed over time and the interim report will be published in six months’ time. Dignity’s recent price initiatives will provide some protection during this process, albeit the company has not yet settled on a new pricing policy. This news is likely to make Dignity look towards lower pricing rather than stick to the full priced traditional funeral. The company has more to be concerned about on the Cremation side as prices have risen substantially over the last decade and crems are effectively local monopolies. The outcome may just be greater visibility on pricing, but this will be unhelpful for Dignity given its current premium pricing.

A special individual shareholder proposal has been tabled for the OGM on 28 June
(sixth proposal on the agenda). This motion proposes adding the following
language to the Articles of Incorporation: “In the case of acquiring shares of a
company whose total consideration exceeds 1 trillion yen …, the Company shall
submit the proposal to and obtain in advance the approval of the Shareholders’
Meeting …” The Takeda Board of Directors objects to the proposal because it
“disturbs agile decision-making and implementation of initiatives.” Takeda
management thinks this proposal will not have an impact on the Shire acquisition.

BE12:02pm

The resulting uncertainty for Dialog’s main business, which raises serious doubts about the strength of its relations with Apple and will likely pressure margins, prompts us to downgrade to Neutral. Although the valuation may seem low, at 0.4x 2019e sales after adjustments, the denominator is so variable depending on the options chosen by Apple that it is hard to get a clear idea of how attractive the stock is. Indeed, with the existence of a second source, which is probably Apple itself, there is a risk that Dialog’s chips could ultimately be replaced completely. And this business with Apple accounts for over 70% of Dialog’s sales. Even in an optimistic scenario in which Dialog remains a major supplier of PMIC for Apple, the fact that there is a second source considerably reduces its negotiating clout, which could weigh on the gross margin for this business.
